column2: LECTURE XV
column3: LECTURE fifteen

column2: THE DISCOVERY OF NEPTUNE
column3: THE DISCOVERY OF NEPTUNE

column2: We approach to-night perhaps the greatest, certainly the most conspicuous, triumphs of the theory of gravitation.
column3: We approach to night perhaps the greatest, certainly the most conspicuous, triumphs of the theory of gravitation.

column2: The explanation by Newton of the observed facts of the motion of the moon, the way he accounted for precession and nutation and for the tides, the way in which Laplace explained every detail of the planetary motions--these achievements may seem to the professional astronomer equally, if not more, striking and wonderful; but of the facts to be explained in these cases the general public are necessarily more or less ignorant, and so no beauty or thoroughness of treatment appeals to them, nor can excite their imaginations.
column3: The explanation by Newton of the observed facts of the motion of the moon, the way he accounted for precession and nutation and for the tides, the way in which Laplace explained every detail of the planetary motions-these achievements may seem to the professional astronomer equally, if not more, striking and wonderful; but of the facts to be explained in these cases the general public are necessarily more or less ignorant, and so no beauty or thoroughness of treatment appeals to them, nor can excite their imaginations.

column2: But to predict in the solitude of the study, with no weapons other than pen, ink, and paper, an unknown and enormously distant world, to calculate its orbit when as yet it had never been seen, and to be able to say to a practical astronomer, "Point your telescope in such a direction at such a time, and you will see a new planet hitherto unknown to man"--this must always appeal to the imagination with dramatic intensity, and must awaken some interest in almost the dullest.
column3: But to predict in the solitude of the study, with no weapons other than pen, ink, and paper, an unknown and enormously distant world, to calculate its orbit when as yet it had never been seen, and to be able to say to a practical astronomer, "Point your telescope in such a direction at such a time, and you will see a new planet hitherto unknown to man"--this must always appeal to the imagination with dramatic intensity, and must awaken some interest in almost the dullest.

column2: Prediction is no novelty in science; and in astronomy least of all is it a novelty.
column3: Prediction is no novelty in science; and in astronomy least of all is it a novelty.

column2: Thousands of years ago, Thales, and others whose very names we have forgotten, could predict eclipses with some certainty, though with only rough accuracy.
column3: Thousands of years ago, Thales, and others whose very names we have forgotten, could predict eclipses with some certainty, though with only rough accuracy.

column2: And many other phenomena were capable of prediction by accumulated experience.
column3: And many other phenomena were capable of prediction by accumulated experience.

column2: We have seen, for instance (coming to later times), how a gap between Mars and Jupiter caused a missing planet to be suspected and looked for, and to be found in a hundred pieces.
column3: We have seen, for instance (coming to later times), how a gap between Mars and Jupiter caused a missing planet to be suspected and looked for, and to be found in a hundred pieces.

column2: We have seen, also, how the abnormal proper-motion of Sirius suggested to Bessel the existence of an unseen companion.
column3: We have seen, also, how the abnormal proper motion of Sirius suggested to Bessel the existence of an unseen companion.

column2: And these last instances seem to approach very near the same class of prediction as that of the discovery of Neptune.
column3: And these last instances seem to approach very near the same class of prediction as that of the discovery of Neptune.

column2: Wherein, then, lies the difference? How comes it that some classes of prediction--such as that if you put your finger in fire it will get burnt--are childishly easy and commonplace, while others excite in the keenest intellects the highest feelings of admiration?
column3: Wherein, then, lies the difference? How comes it that some classes of prediction-such as that if you put your finger in fire it will get burnt-are childishly easy and commonplace, while others excite in the keenest intellects the highest feelings of admiration?

column2: Mainly, the difference lies, first, in the grounds on which the prediction is based; second, on the difficulty of the investigation whereby it is accomplished; third, in the completeness and the accuracy with which it can be verified.
column3: Mainly, the difference lies, first, in the grounds on which the prediction is based; second, on the difficulty of the investigation whereby it is accomplished; third, in the completeness and the accuracy with which it can be verified.

column2: In all these points, the discovery of Neptune stands out pre-eminently among the verified predictions of science, and the circumstances surrounding it are of singular interest.
column3: In all these points, the discovery of Neptune stands out pre eminently among the verified predictions of science, and the circumstances surrounding it are of singular interest.

column2: In 1781, Sir William Herschel discovered the planet Uranus.
column3: In seventeen eighty one, Sir William Herschel discovered the planet Uranus.

column2: Now you know that three distinct observations suffice to determine the orbit of a planet completely, and that it is well to have the three observations as far apart as possible so as to minimize the effects of minute but necessary errors of observation. (See p. 298.) Directly Uranus was found, therefore, old records of stellar observations were ransacked, with the object of discovering whether it had ever been unwittingly seen before.
column3: Now you know that three distinct observations suffice to determine the orbit of a planet completely, and that it is well to have the three observations as far apart as possible so as to minimize the effects of minute but necessary errors of observation. (See p. two hundred ninety eight.) Directly Uranus was found, therefore, old records of stellar observations were ransacked, with the object of discovering whether it had ever been unwittingly seen before.

column2: If seen, it had been thought of course to be a star (for it shines like a star of the sixth magnitude, and can therefore be just seen without a telescope if one knows precisely where to look for it, and if one has good sight), but if it had been seen and catalogued as a star it would have moved from its place, and the catalogue would by that entry be wrong.
column3: If seen, it had been thought of course to be a star (for it shines like a star of the sixth magnitude, and can therefore be just seen without a telescope if one knows precisely where to look for it, and if one has good sight), but if it had been seen and catalogued as a star it would have moved from its place, and the catalogue would by that entry be wrong.

column2: The thing to detect, therefore, was errors in the catalogues: to examine all entries, and see if the stars entered actually existed, or were any of them missing.
column3: The thing to detect, therefore, was errors in the catalogues: to examine all entries, and see if the stars entered actually existed, or were any of them missing.

column2: If a wrong entry were discovered, it might of course have been due to some clerical error, though that is hardly probable considering the care taken over these things, or it might have been some tailless comet or other, or it might have been the newly found planet.
column3: If a wrong entry were discovered, it might of course have been due to some clerical error, though that is hardly probable considering the care taken over these things, or it might have been some tailless comet or other, or it might have been the newly found planet.

column2: So the next thing was to calculate backwards, and see if by any possibility the planet could have been in that place at that time. Examined in this way the tabulated observations of Flamsteed showed that he had unwittingly observed Uranus five distinct times, the first time in 1690, nearly a century before Herschel discovered its true nature. But more remarkable still, Le Monnier, of Paris, had observed it eight times in one month, cataloguing it each time as a different star.
column3: So the next thing was to calculate backwards, and see if by any possibility the planet could have been in that place at that time. Examined in this way the tabulated observations of Flamsteed showed that he had unwittingly observed Uranus five distinct times, the first time in sixteen ninety, nearly a century before Herschel discovered its true nature. But more remarkable still, Le Monnier, of Paris, had observed it eight times in one month, cataloguing it each time as a different star.

column2: If only he had reduced and compared his observations, he would have anticipated Herschel by twelve years.
column3: If only he had reduced and compared his observations, he would have anticipated Herschel by twelve years.

column2: As it was, he missed it altogether.
column3: As it was, he missed it altogether.

column2: It was seen once by Bradley also.
column3: It was seen once by Bradley also.

column2: Altogether it had been seen twenty times.
column3: Altogether it had been seen twenty times.

column2: These old observations of Flamsteed and those of Le Monnier, combined with those made after Herschel's discovery, were very useful in determining an exact orbit for the new planet, and its motion was considered thoroughly known.
column3: These old observations of Flamsteed and those of Le Monnier, combined with those made after Herschel's discovery, were very useful in determining an exact orbit for the new planet, and its motion was considered thoroughly known.

column2: It was not an _exact_ ellipse, of course: none of the planets describe _exact_ ellipses--each perturbs all the rest, and these small perturbations must be taken into account, those of Jupiter and Saturn being by far the most important.
column3: It was not an underscore exact underscore ellipse, of course: none of the planets describe underscore exact underscore ellipses-each perturbs all the rest, and these small perturbations must be taken into account, those of Jupiter and Saturn being by far the most important.

column2: For a time Uranus seemed to travel regularly and as expected, in the orbit which had been calculated for it; but early in the present century it began to be slightly refractory, and by 1820 its actual place showed quite a distinct discrepancy from its position as calculated with the aid of the old observations.
column3: For a time Uranus seemed to travel regularly and as expected, in the orbit which had been calculated for it; but early in the present century it began to be slightly refractory, and by eighteen twenty its actual place showed quite a distinct discrepancy from its position as calculated with the aid of the old observations.

column2: It was at first thought that this discrepancy must be due to inaccuracies in the older observations, and they were accordingly rejected, and tables prepared for the planet based on the newer and more accurate observations only.
column3: It was at first thought that this discrepancy must be due to inaccuracies in the older observations, and they were accordingly rejected, and tables prepared for the planet based on the newer and more accurate observations only.

column2: But by 1830 it became apparent that it would not accurately obey even these.
column3: But by eighteen thirty it became apparent that it would not accurately obey even these.

column2: The error amounted to some 20".
column3: The error amounted to some twenty inches.

column2: By 1840 it was as much as 90', or a minute and a half.
column3: By eighteen forty it was as much as ninety feet, or a minute and a half.

column2: This discrepancy is quite distinct, but still it is very small, and had two objects been in the heavens at once, the actual Uranus and the theoretical Uranus, no unaided eye could possibly have distinguished them or detected that they were other than a single star.
column3: This discrepancy is quite distinct, but still it is very small, and had two objects been in the heavens at once, the actual Uranus and the theoretical Uranus, no unaided eye could possibly have distinguished them or detected that they were other than a single star.

column2: The errors of Uranus therefore, though small, were enormously greater than things which had certainly been observed; there was an unmistakable discrepancy between theory and observation.
column3: The errors of Uranus therefore, though small, were enormously greater than things which had certainly been observed; there was an unmistakable discrepancy between theory and observation.

column2: Some cause was evidently at work on this distant planet, causing it to disagree with its motion as calculated according to the law of gravitation.
column3: Some cause was evidently at work on this distant planet, causing it to disagree with its motion as calculated according to the law of gravitation.

column2: Some thought that the exact law of gravitation did not apply to so distant a body.
column3: Some thought that the exact law of gravitation did not apply to so distant a body.

column2: Others surmised the presence of some foreign and unknown body, some comet, or some still more distant planet perhaps, whose gravitative attraction for Uranus was the cause of the whole difficulty--some perturbations, in fact, which had not been taken into account because of our ignorance of the existence of the body which caused them.
column3: Others surmised the presence of some foreign and unknown body, some comet, or some still more distant planet perhaps, whose gravitative attraction for Uranus was the cause of the whole difficulty-some perturbations, in fact, which had not been taken into account because of our ignorance of the existence of the body which caused them.

column2: But though such an idea was mentioned among astronomers, it was not regarded with any special favour, and was considered merely as one among a number of hypotheses which could be suggested as fairly probable.
column3: But though such an idea was mentioned among astronomers, it was not regarded with any special favour, and was considered merely as one among a number of hypotheses which could be suggested as fairly probable.

column2: It is perfectly right not to attach much importance to unelaborated guesses.
column3: It is perfectly right not to attach much importance to unelaborated guesses.

column2: Not until the consequences of an hypothesis have been laboriously worked out--not until it can be shown capable of producing the effect quantitatively as well as qualitatively--does its statement rise above the level of a guess, and attain the dignity of a theory.
column3: Not until the consequences of an hypothesis have been laboriously worked out-not until it can be shown capable of producing the effect quantitatively as well as qualitatively-does its statement rise above the level of a guess, and attain the dignity of a theory.

column2: A later stage still occurs when the theory has been actually and completely verified by agreement with observation.
column3: A later stage still occurs when the theory has been actually and completely verified by agreement with observation.

column2: In 1841 the difficulties of the problem presented by these residual perturbations of Uranus excited the imagination of a young student, an undergraduate of St. John's College, Cambridge--John Couch Adams by name--and he determined to have a try at it as soon as he was through his Tripos.
column3: In eighteen forty one the difficulties of the problem presented by these residual perturbations of Uranus excited the imagination of a young student, an undergraduate of saint John's College, Cambridge-john Couch Adams by name-and he determined to have a try at it as soon as he was through his Tripos.

column2: In January, 1843, he graduated as Senior Wrangler, and shortly afterwards he set to work.
column3: In January, eighteen forty three, he graduated as Senior Wrangler, and shortly afterwards he set to work.

column2: In less than two years he reached a definite conclusion; and in October, 1845, he wrote to the Astronomer-Royal, at Greenwich, Professor Airy, saying that the perturbations of Uranus would be explained by assuming the existence of an outer planet, which he reckoned was now situated in a specified latitude and longitude.
column3: In less than two years he reached a definite conclusion; and in October, eighteen forty five, he wrote to the Astronomer Royal, at Greenwich, Professor Airy, saying that the perturbations of Uranus would be explained by assuming the existence of an outer planet, which he reckoned was now situated in a specified latitude and longitude.

column2: We know now that had the Astronomer-Royal put sufficient faith in this result to point his big telescope to the spot indicated and commence sweeping for a planet, he would have detected it within 1-3/4 deg. of the place assigned to it by Mr. Adams.

column2: But any one in the position of the Astronomer-Royal knows that almost every post brings an absurd letter from some ambitious correspondent or other, some of them having just discovered perpetual motion, or squared the circle, or proved the earth flat, or discovered the constitution of the moon, or of ether, or of electricity; and out of this mass of rubbish it requires great skill and patience to detect such gems of value as there may be.

column2: Now this letter of Mr. Adams's was indeed a jewel of the first water, and no doubt bore on its face a very different appearance from the chaff of which I have spoken; but still Mr. Adams was an unknown man: he had graduated as Senior Wrangler it is true, but somebody must graduate as Senior Wrangler every year, and every year by no means produces a first-rate mathematician.

column3: He then set to work to consider the perturbations produced by Jupiter and Saturn, to see if they had been with perfect accuracy allowed for, or whether some minute improvements could be made sufficient to destroy the irregularities.

column2: He next examined the various hypotheses that had been suggested to account for them:--Was it a failure in the law of gravitation?

column2: Before that date Uranus had been hurried along, and after that date it had been retarded, by the pull of Neptune, and thus the observed discrepancies from its computed place were produced.
column3: Before that date Uranus had been hurried along, and after that date it had been retarded, by the pull of Neptune, and thus the observed discrepancies from its computed place were produced.

column2: The problem was first to disentangle the outstanding perturbations from those which would be caused by Jupiter and Saturn and all other known causes, and then to assign the place of an outer planet able to produce precisely those perturbations in Uranus.]
column3: The problem was first to disentangle the outstanding perturbations from those which would be caused by Jupiter and Saturn and all other known causes, and then to assign the place of an outer planet able to produce precisely those perturbations in Uranus.]

column2: Not without failures and disheartening complications was this part of the process completed.
column3: Not without failures and disheartening complications was this part of the process completed.

column2: This was, after all, the real tug of war.
column3: This was, after all, the real tug of war.

column2: So many unknown quantities: its mass, its distance, its excentricity, the obliquity of its orbit, its position at any time--nothing known, in fact, about the planet except the microscopic disturbance it caused in Uranus, some thousand million miles away from it.
column3: So many unknown quantities: its mass, its distance, its excentricity, the obliquity of its orbit, its position at any time-nothing known, in fact, about the planet except the microscopic disturbance it caused in Uranus, some thousand million miles away from it.

column2: Without going into further detail, suffice it to say that in June, 1846, he published his last paper, and in it announced to the world his theoretical position for the planet.
column3: Without going into further detail, suffice it to say that in June, eighteen forty six, he published his last paper, and in it announced to the world his theoretical position for the planet.

column2: Professor Airy received a copy of this paper before the end of the month, and was astonished to find that Leverrier's theoretical place for the planet was within 1 deg. of the place Mr. Adams had assigned to it eight months before.
column3: Professor Airy received a copy of this paper before the end of the month, and was astonished to find that Leverrier's theoretical place for the planet was within one d e g. of the place mr Adams had assigned to it eight months before.

column2: So striking a coincidence seemed sufficient to justify a Herschelian "sweep" for a week or two.
column3: So striking a coincidence seemed sufficient to justify a Herschelian "sweep" for a week or two.

column2: But a sweep for so distant a planet would be no easy matter.
column3: But a sweep for so distant a planet would be no easy matter.

column2: When seen in a large telescope it would still only look like a star, and it would require considerable labour and watching to sift it out from the other stars surrounding it.
column3: When seen in a large telescope it would still only look like a star, and it would require considerable labour and watching to sift it out from the other stars surrounding it.

column2: We know that Uranus had been seen twenty times, and thought to be a star, before its true nature was by Herschel discovered; and Uranus is only about half as far away as Neptune is.
column3: We know that Uranus had been seen twenty times, and thought to be a star, before its true nature was by Herschel discovered; and Uranus is only about half as far away as Neptune is.

column2: Neither in Paris nor yet at Greenwich was any optical search undertaken; but Professor Airy wrote to ask M. Leverrier the same old question as he had fruitlessly put to Mr. Adams: Did the new theory explain the errors of the radius vector or not?
column3: Neither in Paris nor yet at Greenwich was any optical search undertaken; but Professor Airy wrote to ask m Leverrier the same old question as he had fruitlessly put to mr Adams: Did the new theory explain the errors of the radius vector or not?

column2: The reply of Leverrier was both prompt and satisfactory--these errors were explained, as well as all the others. The existence of the object was then for the first time officially believed in.
column3: The reply of Leverrier was both prompt and satisfactory-these errors were explained, as well as all the others. The existence of the object was then for the first time officially believed in.

column2: The British Association met that year at Southampton, and Sir John Herschel was one of its Sectional Presidents.
column3: The British Association met that year at Southampton, and Sir john Herschel was one of its Sectional Presidents.

column2: In his inaugural address, on September 10th, 1846, he called attention to the researches of Leverrier and Adams in these memorable words:--
column3: In his inaugural address, on september tenth eighteen forty six, he called attention to the researches of Leverrier and Adams in these memorable words:--

column2: The past year has given to us the new [minor] planet Astraea; it has done more--it has given us the probable prospect of another. We see it as Columbus saw America from the shores of Spain.	The past year has given to us the new [minor] planet Astraea; it has done more-it has given us the probable prospect of another. We see it as Columbus saw America from the shores of Spain.
column3: true

column2: Its movements have been felt trembling along the far-reaching line of our analysis with a certainty hardly inferior to ocular demonstration."
column3: Its movements have been felt trembling along the far reaching line of our analysis with a certainty hardly inferior to ocular demonstration."

column2: It was about time to begin to look for it.
column3: It was about time to begin to look for it.

column2: So the Astronomer-Royal thought on reading Leverrier's paper.
column3: So the Astronomer Royal thought on reading Leverrier's paper.

column2: But as the national telescope at Greenwich was otherwise occupied, he wrote to Professor Challis, at Cambridge, to know if he would permit a search to be made for it with the Northumberland Equatoreal, the large telescope of Cambridge University, presented to it by one of the Dukes of Northumberland.
column3: But as the national telescope at Greenwich was otherwise occupied, he wrote to Professor Challis, at Cambridge, to know if he would permit a search to be made for it with the Northumberland Equatoreal, the large telescope of Cambridge University, presented to it by one of the Dukes of Northumberland.

column2: Professor Challis said he would conduct the search himself; and shortly commenced a leisurely and dignified series of sweeps round about the place assigned by theory, cataloguing all the stars which he observed, intending afterwards to sort out his observations, compare one with another, and find out whether any one star had changed its position; because if it had it must be the planet.
column3: Professor Challis said he would conduct the search himself; and shortly commenced a leisurely and dignified series of sweeps round about the place assigned by theory, cataloguing all the stars which he observed, intending afterwards to sort out his observations, compare one with another, and find out whether any one star had changed its position; because if it had it must be the planet.

column2: He thus, without giving an excessive time to the business, accumulated a host of observations, which he intended afterwards to reduce and sift at his leisure.
column3: He thus, without giving an excessive time to the business, accumulated a host of observations, which he intended afterwards to reduce and sift at his leisure.

column2: The wretched man thus actually saw the planet twice--on August 4th and August 12th, 1846--without knowing it.
column3: The wretched man thus actually saw the planet twice-on august fourth and august twelfth eighteen forty six--without knowing it.

column2: If only he had had a map of the heavens containing telescopic stars down to the tenth magnitude, and if he had compared his observations with this map as they were made, the process would have been easy, and the discovery quick.
column3: If only he had had a map of the heavens containing telescopic stars down to the tenth magnitude, and if he had compared his observations with this map as they were made, the process would have been easy, and the discovery quick.

column2: But he had no such map.
column3: But he had no such map.

column2: Nevertheless one was in existence: it had just been completed in that country of enlightened method and industry--Germany.
column3: Nevertheless one was in existence: it had just been completed in that country of enlightened method and industry-Germany.

column2: Dr. Bremiker had not, indeed, completed his great work--a chart of the whole zodiac down to stars of the tenth magnitude--but portions of it were completed, and the special region where the new planet was expected happened to be among the portions already just done.
column3: dr Bremiker had not, indeed, completed his great work-a chart of the whole zodiac down to stars of the tenth magnitude-but portions of it were completed, and the special region where the new planet was expected happened to be among the portions already just done.

column2: But in England this was not known.
column3: But in England this was not known.

column2: Meanwhile, Mr. Adams wrote to the Astronomer-Royal several additional communications, making improvements in his theory, and giving what he considered nearer and nearer approximations for the place of the planet. He also now answered quite satisfactorily, but too late, the question about the radius vector sent to him months before.
column3: Meanwhile, mr Adams wrote to the Astronomer Royal several additional communications, making improvements in his theory, and giving what he considered nearer and nearer approximations for the place of the planet. He also now answered quite satisfactorily, but too late, the question about the radius vector sent to him months before.

column2: Let us return to Leverrier.
column3: Let us return to Leverrier.

column2: This great man was likewise engaged in improving his theory and in considering how best the optical search could be conducted.
column3: This great man was likewise engaged in improving his theory and in considering how best the optical search could be conducted.

column2: Actuated, probably, by the knowledge that in such matters as cataloguing and mapping Germany was then, as now, far ahead of all the other nations of the world, he wrote in September (the same September as Sir John Herschel delivered his eloquent address at Southampton) to Berlin.
column3: Actuated, probably, by the knowledge that in such matters as cataloguing and mapping Germany was then, as now, far ahead of all the other nations of the world, he wrote in September (the same September as Sir john Herschel delivered his eloquent address at Southampton) to Berlin.

column2: Leverrier wrote, I say, to Dr. Galle, head of the Observatory at Berlin, saying to him, clearly and decidedly, that the new planet was now in or close to such and such a position, and that if he would point his telescope to that part of the heavens he would see it; and, moreover, that he would be able to tell it from a star by its having a sensible magnitude, or disk, instead of being a mere point.
column3: Leverrier wrote, I say, to dr Galle, head of the Observatory at Berlin, saying to him, clearly and decidedly, that the new planet was now in or close to such and such a position, and that if he would point his telescope to that part of the heavens he would see it; and, moreover, that he would be able to tell it from a star by its having a sensible magnitude, or disk, instead of being a mere point.
